node.title: Wrongly jailed man feared being raped by inmate after being told to shave legs, court told
node.description: A man suing a Federal Court judge who wrongly jailed him for contempt during divorce proceedings, says his time in jail has left him traumatised and unable to work.

node.title: Police to set up two checkpoints at Auckland-Northland border
node.description: Police say they will set up two checkpoints in Northland with local iwi to check for vaccination or proof of a negative Covid-19 test.

node.title: Texas Highway Department Says 'Let's Go Brandon' Road Sign is Not Theirs
node.description: The state's highway department said the sign was posted by a contractor, and not the state itself.

node.title: 'We are going to bring every one of them home here': Aboriginal ancestral remains laid to rest as museum says sorry
node.description: After decades of pain and anguish for Kaurna people, the first repatriations of Aboriginal ancestral remains have been laid to rest on Country, with the SA Museum apologising for holding 4,600 Aboriginal remains over the past 165 years.

node.title: A Supreme Court storm is brewing for American women
node.description: Since 2016 a wave of abortion bans in the US take aim at the landmark 1973 Supreme Court decision that guaranteed abortion as a constitutional right. Now a new case in the US Supreme Court is the most significant threat to abortion rights in the US in decades.

node.title: Proposals for changes to political donations released
node.description: The government quietly released a number of proposals, which are now out for public feedback.

node.title: Can Germany’s New Chancellor Revive the Left in Europe?
node.description: Olaf Scholz wants to win back workers who defected to the populist far right. Success could make him a model for Social Democrats everywhere.

node.title: Myanmar court sentences Suu Kyi to four years in jail
node.description: Ousted Myanmar leader Aung San Suu Kyi has been sentenced to four years in prison, in the first in a series of verdicts that could jail her for life.

node.title: In This Novel, Art Is the Key to Another’s Consciousness
node.description: “White on White,” by Aysegul Savas, is a study of interiority told through exchanges between a scholar and a painter.

node.title: In the US, a boss sacked 900 staff over video call — but could it happen here?
node.description: A US mortgage company sacked hundreds of employees over video call just before Christmas, but experts say there are protections against that behaviour in Australia.

node.title: Law change makes drug testing at festivals easier, policing issues remain
node.description: The Drug and Substance Checking Legislation Act 2021 has made it easier for drug testers to operate at festivals. But there's more work to be done to ensure young people remain safe, advocates say.

node.title: Farmers still face higher rates of suicide with one death every 10 days in Australia
node.description: Drought, relationship breakdown, underlying depression, and easy access to guns are found to be key risk factors in a suicide rate 60 per cent higher than rates among non-farmers.

node.title: 'Fuelled by hate, division, and misinformation': Persecuted refugees suing Facebook for $US150 billion
node.description: Rohingya refugees are seeking more than $200 billion in a lawsuit against Facebook for allegedly failing to stem hate speech on its platform and exacerbating violence against the vulnerable Myanmar minority.

node.title: 'I was slightly horrified': Mother recounts seven-week-old baby's COVID swab amid SA hotel quarantine saga
node.description: A new mother and her baby have been bundled into a medi-hotel, despite having a permit to quarantine at home after landing in Adelaide, as questions mount about the systems in place for travellers returning to SA.

node.title: Steadily-rising interest rates on the way, RBNZ officials say
node.description: Inflation is set to stay high for some time forcing the Reserve Bank to combat it with steadily rising interest rates, according to two of the central bank's most senior officials.

node.title: Man facing several charges after Dunedin bar incident remanded in custody
node.description: A Dunedin man who allegedly threatened people with a knife after he failed to produce a Covid-19 vaccine pass in a central city bar, has been remanded in custody.

node.title: Two schools wrongly claim $170k under wage subsidy scheme
node.description: The Auditor-General says two schools were wrongly awarded money, with one school claiming $49,000 because its fundraising event was cancelled.

node.title: Sydney Opera House Extends Six-Figure Contract for Dogs That Chase Seagulls
node.description: The Opera House said that the dogs "greatly improve the experience of our visitors."

node.title: Billionaire with 'rapacious appetite' for stolen antiquities agrees to hand over nearly $100m in looted artefacts
node.description: Michael Steinhardt cut deals with "tomb raiders" to get his hands on looted artefacts from countries including Greece, Israel and Iraq, according to New York prosecutors.

node.title: Reserve Bank 'prepared to be patient' as interest rates kept at record lows into 2022
node.description: The Reserve Bank keeps interest rates at a record low and maintains its current stimulus, re-emphasising its patience to see inflation and wages growth increase more sustainably before considering a rate rise.

node.title: Police to Search Home of Artist Who Allowed Crumbleys to Stay in His Detroit Studio
node.description: The artist said he didn't realize that police were searching for the parental pair when he allowed them to stay in his studio.

node.title: Missed debt repayments increased by 8 percent in November
node.description: More people are falling behind on personal debt repayments at the same time as demand for retail finance increases.

node.title: Intel Will Take Mobileye Public in 2022
node.description: The chip maker’s Israeli subsidiary builds driver-assistance technology for major automakers and is now testing self-driving cars.

node.title: Volunteer Dies After a Sheep Charges at Her on a Therapy Farm
node.description: Kim Taylor, 73, went into cardiac arrest after being attacked while caring for livestock at a Massachusetts farm, the police said.

node.title: Pence's Former Top Aide, Once Banned From the White House, Cooperating With Jan. 6 Committee
node.description: Pence's former chief of staff Marc Short, who was with Pence as he fled while insurrectionists were invading the Capitol, will speak to the House panel.

node.title: Nurse accused of faking teenager's COVID vaccination has fraud charge dropped
node.description: Police drop a fraud charge against a Perth nurse who was accused of falsely recording that a teenager had been given a COVID-19 vaccine, when the jab was never administered.

node.title: Home detention for selling livestock that didn't exist
node.description: While working for Rural Livestock Limited, John Francis Williams defrauded his employer as well as his clients by submitting false sale notes related to livestock sales and leasing agreements.

node.title: Covid-19: Hut in Fiordland National Park identified as a high-risk exposure site
node.description: A Department of Conservation hut in Fiordland National Park has been identified as a high-risk Covid-19 exposure site.

node.title: 1/6 Rioter Who Said She'd Avoid Jail Because She's 'White' Now Plans to 'Detox' in Prison
node.description: She listed yoga and working out as two of the activities she hoped to do while behind bars.

node.title: Man Arrested in 2018 for 1987 Cold Case Has Conviction Overturned Because of Juror Bias
node.description: The juror had experience of violence against a woman and didn't know if she, as a mother, could remain unbiased during the trial, she said.
